clinical_study.brief_title: Treatment of Recent Onset Low Back Pain With Periradicular Injections of Meloxicam
clinical_study.official_title: Treatment of Recent Onset Low Back Pain With Periradicular Injections of Meloxicam: a Randomized, Double Blind, Placebo Controlled Cross-over Study

brief_summary.textblock: This randomized, double-blind, placebo control, cross-over study tested the hypothesis that periradicular injections of Meloxicam would reduce recent onset low back pain and improve physical activity compared to saline injection at 3 months follow-up evaluation

detailed_description.textblock: In the present study we use a well-known non steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, meloxicam, in a novel way, an IM administration near a nerve root.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline NRS pain scale score at different consecutive follow up assessments
primary_outcome.description: Patients reported a numeric value to evaluate pain (0= no pain, 10= wrost pain)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline level of physical activities and life quality at different consecutive follow up yes/no questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: pain-related insomnia, physical assistance, sport activities, work absence were assessed using a structured questionnaire with dichotomous items (yes/no presence of impairment to the selected item)

arm_group.description: patients receiving an IM saline injection near the nerve root (periradicular)
patients receiving an IM Meloxicam injection near the nerve root (periradicular)

intervention.description: The patients received an IM injection of saline near the nerve root (periradicular)
The patients received an IM injection of meloxicam near the nerve root (periradicular)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- low back pain from 6 months or less
- older than 18 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- not able to understand and sign the written informed consent
